slidelink.displaytext: Unit 3.3: Equipment Depreciation and Replacement Strategies

slidetranscripts.slidetranscript:
In Unit 1:

- You will be able to explain power considerations for heavy civil equipment, including rolling resistance, gradient, traction, altitude, and minimizing power requirements.

In Unit 2:

- You will be able to analyze cycle times, fixed time, variable time, and operating efficiency

- You will be able to calculate basic parameters used to select heavy equipment, such as Rimpull requirements, number of cycles, and cycle times.

- In Unit 3:

- You will be able to calculate equipment cost and depreciation, and you will be able to evaluate equipment replacement strategies.

Equipment Power

Earthmoving operation is a dynamic system, with several components interacting in a complex system.

For example, the following diagram shows a common cyclic earthmoving operation.

First, loading unit, excavator in this case, loads a hauling equipment.

Then the hauling machine carries the load to the dumping area.

Then the hauling machine discharges the load in the designated area.

Next the hauling machine returns to the loading area and the cycle continues.

Machine Power

There are three factors that are required to analyze machine power: Estimated required power, available power, and estimated usable power.

First, we are going to discuss how to estimate required power.

1. Required Power

The required power is the power needed to overcome existing resistance. To determine if the piece of equipment has enough required power to complete the task, construction personnel would have to calculate for Total Resistance, Rolling Resistance and Grade Resistance, which are two types of resistance against the operating equipment.

First, is rolling resistance, also called Track Resistance, is the resistance of a level surface against constant velocity of a moving machine

Second item is grade resistance which is the result of gravity force

Rolling Resistance

Several factors can affect rolling resistance.

First factor is the condition of the surface.

Equipment tires can sink in the soft surfaces, and they have to constantly climb out of the ruts, Therefore the rolling resistance is high in soft surfaces.

In contrast, hard surfaces has much lower rolling resistance compared to the soft surfaces.

Sinking of a tire in soft ground will drastically increase the rolling resistance

Because the tire has to always climb out of the rut. It is estimated that each centimeter of penetration increases the rolling resistance about 5.4 kg per ton of the equipment weight

Rolling Resistance (Track Resistance)

The second factor on rolling resistance is the tire condition for equipment with rubber tires.

This table describe effectiveness of different tires in different surface conditions.

Narrow-tread and high pressure tires have low rolling resistance in hard surfaces due to low contact area.

Wide-tread and low pressure tires have high rolling resistance in hard surfaces due to high contact area.

Narrow-tread and high pressure tires have high rolling resistance in soft surfaces due to deeper sinking in the soft surface.

Wide-tread and low pressure tires have lower rolling resistance in soft surfaces due to lower level of sinking in the soft surface.

Calculate Rolling Resistance

Rolling resistance is expressed as kilogram force resistance per metric ton of gross equipment weight in a level surface.

To calculate for Rolling Resistance, let’s assume this truck is on a level surface with gross weight of W in tons.

Then we want to pull the equipment on this surface using a cable.

The tension force in the towing cable is the required force to overcome the total rolling resistance.

Then rolling resistance is calculated by dividing this tension force by the gross weight of the equipment.

Sample Rolling Resistance

This table presents some sample rolling resistance for low pressure and high pressure tires as well as crawler track in different surface types.

As presented here, quality of the can significantly affect the rolling resistance of the surface, therefore it is essential for site engineers to decide on the quality of access road and invest to maintain a good quality surface to decrease operation cost of the equipment and increase their productivity.

Grade Resistance

The second type of resistance is Grade resistance which is the opposing force due the gravity in a frictionless slope.

As it is illustrated here, the grade resistance is the force element of the equipment in the movement direction of the machine.

So as the slope of the surface increases, the sine also increase which results in the increase of the grade resistance.

Calculate Grade Resistance

Since it is common to describe slope in percent, we can simplify grade resistance and express it in terms of percent as well.

The slope of the grade in percentage is equals to the height highlight red H in the right side of image divided by the distance highlight red L in the bottom of image times 100.

In small angles, which is 0 to about 10 degrees, the sine of an angle is very close to its tangent. Most roads have a slope smaller than 10 degrees, so we can consider that sine of the slope angle is approximately equal to its tangent.

Then the rolling resistance can be rewritten as resistance force equals to the weight times tangent of the alpha.

Since tangent of the alpha equals to H divided by L, thus we can say that the rolling resistance equals to the weight times slope divided by 100.

So we can say that the rolling resistance is equal to 10 kg for each metric ton of the gross weight of vehicle multiplied by the slope percentage.

Total Resistance

Both grade and rolling resistances are expressed in kg/ton.

Grade resistance is equal to 10 Kg/ton x G%, or the main variable is the slope or grade.

Rolling resistance can be expressed in equivalent gradient as it is presented in this formula: G% is equal to the rolling resistance expressed in kg/ton divided by 10 kg/ton

To simplify calculations and the concept, we can also rewrite the rolling resistance in the form of slope. Although they are different in nature, this simplification would facilitate the process.

Finally, the total resistance can be expressed in the form slope gradient, called effective grade.

Effective grade (%) = Rolling resistance(%) + Grade resistance (%)

Total Resistance: Exercise

A haul road from the quarry to processing site has a grade of 5%. The expected rolling resistance of the road for this type of dump truck is 55 kg/ton. Calculate the effective grades for haul and return trips.

Total Resistance: Solution

To solve this, first you must calculate the Equivalent grade for rolling resistance, which is equal 55 divided by 10 to equal 5.5%.

Then solve for Effective Grade for haul trips, which is equal to 5% + 5.5%, which is equal to 10.5%

Lastly, solve for the Effective Grade for return trips. This is equal to 5.5% - 5% (negative because it is downhill), which is equal to 0.5%.

Quiz 1:

Rank the following roads based on their rolling resistance (high, medium or low):

A muddy road, gravel and paved road.

Quiz 2:

Given the table (use average values), find the total resistance for a bulldozer in a road with 1% downhill slope in a poorly maintained muddy road.

2. Available Power

As mentioned before, available power is another key factor that should be considered in equipment intensive operations.

Available power of equipment depends on two main factors:

• Horsepower of the equipment

• Speed of the equipment

Equipment Horsepower

Engine horsepower is measured at the flywheel, therefore the output of the equipment engine in different revolution per minute (rpm) is called flywheel horsepower (fwhp).

Manufacturers provide the flywheel horsepower of their equipment, but in practice, a portion of the provided power by engine is lost in the process of transmission from the engine to the wheels or crawler system.

Thus the available power in the wheels or crawler is less than the expressed engine power, but power losses happen during transmission of power from engine to the wheels or crawler system.

Calculate Available Power

Available Power is:

• Point of contact between the tire and surface, called rimpull (in wheel machines)

• Available force in drawbar, called drawbar pull (track machines)

Using the following simple formula, we can estimate the available power a piece of equipment by looking at its rated power.

For example, if a flywheel horsepower of a machine is 200 and the efficiency of powertrain is 0.85, then the available horsepower is 170 horsepower.

Available power is a portion of fwhp, depending on the efficiency of the powertrain system.

This efficiency is usually 80% to 85%.

Calculate Rimpull Power

The rimpull power has inverse relation with the equipment speed.

With this formula, we can calculate the available power (or rimpull power) of the machine in different speeds. In this formula, the horse power and efficiency are constant for a certain equipment, but the speed can vary, so the available power decreases as the speed increases. And that is why heavy equipment operate with very low speeds while doing heavy operations. For example, dump trucks can travel fast when they are empty, but their speed and acceleration dramatically drop when they are loaded .

This means that as the equipment speeds up, the available power between the tire and surface decreases. So that is the reason heavy equipment usually operate in slow speeds during heavy construction operations.

Calculation Example

What is the rimpull for a wheel tractor with 150 hp engine and maximum speed of 3.5 mph in first gear?

Rimpull = 375 x hp (horsepower) x efficiency / speed (mph)

Rimpull = 375 x 150 x 0.85 / 3.5 = 13,661 lb

Quiz 3:

What is the rimpull for a wheel tractor with 150 hp engine (efficiency 0.85) and maximum speed of 7.3 mph in second gear?

2,100 kg

2,971 kg

3,600 kg

6,000 kg

Calculation Example 2

A tractor has a weight of 11 tons, and maximum rimpull of 6,130 kg in the first gear. This machine has to operate in a surface with 3% slope and a rolling resistance of 45 kg/ton.

To calculate the available power for towing, we need to subtract the total resistance from the rimpull.

3. Usable Power

Usable power depends on the jobsite conditions, mainly surface condition and location altitude.

The traction level of a surface affects the amount available power that could be used. Providing more power than the existing surface traction will result in slippage of the wheel or track.

This formula helps us estimate the usable of force of a machine in different site conditions. The weight of equipment is the same in different fields, but the coefficient of traction varies in different surfaces.

For the track type equipment, such as dozers, use the total weight of equipment.

For two axle wheeled equipment, such as dump truck, use 50% of weight of equipment.

Sample coefficients

This table provides important information about traction of different moving mechanism in different types of grounds.

For example, the traction of the rubber wheels is much higher in dry and hard grounds, and it drastically reduced in wet and soft surfaces. The crawler tracks, however, provide better traction in soft and wet grounds. This coefficients can help us to select a right type of equipment based on the job site conditions.

Calculation Example

The weight on a driving axle of a rubber-tired equipment is 9 tons and the maximum rimpull on the low gear is 4,300 kg. The coefficient of traction is 0.35.

If the same equipment operates on dry loam with the coefficient of traction is 0.6.

Quiz 4:

The weight of a bulldozer is 22 tons and the maximum rimpull on the low gear is 9,300 kg. Is that possible to use all the available power on Wet loam? How about wet gravel?

2. Location Altitude

Location of the jobsite, particularly the altitude, also plays a key role in the useable power of the equipment.

The flywheel horsepower indicated in the equipment handbook is typically measured at the sea level and 15 degree celsius. This condition is considered as an optimal operational condition for a combustion engine, because the air is dense and has high pressure, which provides high level of oxygen required for combustion.

But if a machine operates in higher altitudes from sea level the density of the air decreases which results in lower available engine power.

Quiz 5:

A dump truck will operate more efficiently in:

a. Dry gravel road in 500m from sea level

b. Wet gravel road in 500m from sea level

c. Dry gravel road in 1200m from sea level

d. Wet gravel road in 1200m from sea level

Summary of Unit 1

The summary of the items that we discussed in this unit:

1. Required power is estimated based on the load to be moved, rolling resistance, and grade resistance

2. Rolling resistance depends on the surface and tire conditions

3. Total resistance can be express in the form of slope gradient

4. A portion engine power is lost during transmission

5. The usable power should be estimated based on the weight on driving wheels and traction of the surface

Equipment Productivity

Earthmoving operation is a dynamic system, with several components interacting in a complex system.

For example, the following diagram shows a common cyclic earthmoving operation.

First, loading unit, excavator in this case, loads a hauling equipment.

Then the hauling machine carries the load to the dumping area.

Then the hauling machine discharges the load in the designated area.

Next the hauling machine returns to the loading area and the cycle continues.

Phelps Method

In order to keep on schedule for a construction task, a site manager would have to ensure that all of the equipment is capable of completing the task on time. Therefore, they must effectively plan their operations and estimate expenses of their equipment’s intensive tasks. To do this, site engineers can use the Phelps method to help them estimate cycle times of their operations and estimate production rates of their equipment fleet.

Based on the Phelps’ method, cycle times include:

Fixed time

Variable time

Loading time

Fixed Time

Fixed time includes the delays that exist in the earthmoving cycles due to mechanical constraints and human factors.

These delays are inherent in each cycle and happen due to practical constraints, such as the time needed for acceleration or deceleration of the trucks.

These times can be considered as a fix time in the calculations.

Fixed Time Estimation

The main items in the fixed time include:

Acceleration

Deceleration

Turns (operators need to slow down)

Dumping

Non productive time (For example 5 to 15 minutes per hour that the operators take break)

Loading Time

Following table* can be used for estimation of the fixed times (F).

As it is presented in this table, the fix time for longer hauls are smaller, because the trucker are less likely to waste time when engaged in longer drives.

These times only include one acceleration and deceleration for each haul and return. Intermediate stops should be considered.

In the short haul cycles, 60 to 370 meters, the fixed time can be estimated as four and a half minutes.

In medium and long hauls, the fixed time decreases, because the operator has longer distance to accelerate and decelerate, therefore these processes will be more smooth than shorter distances.

Loading Time Factors

Loading time mainly depends on the characteristics of the loading equipment, and the calculation parameters and values are typically provided by the manufacturer.

Variable Time

Variable time includes the time required for haul and return trips. These time can be calculated using the speed and distance of each trip.

Dump truck manufacturers usually provide performance charts to estimate speed based on the gross weight of the equipment, and the rolling and grade resistance of the road in haul and return directions.

Performance Chart

This figure shows a performance chart for a sample 22-ton dump truck.

The process to use the performance chart is as follows:

1. Find the vehicle weight, which could be empty or loaded, in the horizontal axis of the left chart. The minimum weight is the empty weight or net vehicle weight (show the green ring), and the maximum possible weight is the loaded truck to the full capacity, which is Gross Vehicle Weight (show the red ring). For example, lets assume the truck is half full with total weight of 60000 lb ****

2. Read the intersection of the vehicle weight line with the inclined total resistance line, which includes both rolling and grade resistance expressed in %. For example, the 60000 lb dump truck should operate in an uphill road with the slope of 2% and the equivalent rolling resistance of 4%. Thus the total resistance is equal to 4+2 which is 6%. So we need to find the intersection of the vehicle weight line with the 6% total resistance line

3. Extend a horizontal line from the intersection to the right chart to intersect with the performance curve

4. Read down the intersection to find the speed of the vehicle

5. The speed of the vehicle in this example is 12 mph

So this means that this type of dump trucks can travel with 12 miles per hour when it has a total weight of 60’000 lb and operates in a road with total resistance of 6%

Similar procedure is used to estimate return velocity, where the truck is empty

Variable Time Calculations

Similar procedure is used to estimate return velocity:

RR is the rimpull, W_E is the weight of empty truck, and S is the slope (%) in the return direction.

Then given the velocities and the haul distance (d in miles).

Calculating Production

Following step by step procedure, which presented as an example, is used to calculate production of an earthmoving fleet

A 22-ton dump truck has a capacity of 15 cubic yards. The net vehicle weight is 36860 pounds and total gross weight of the equipment should not exceed 80,860 lb. An excavator with a 3.3 cy bucket is used to load trucks. Density of soil is 2,170 lb per cy. (more information will be given in the progress).

So by having the net and maximum gross weights of this truck, we can find the maximum payload, which is 44000 pounds or 22 us tons.

1. Number of Buckets

First step is to determine the number of required buckets to fill a dump truck.

This formula basically calculates the number of bucket loads required to fill the open-box bed of a truck.

So given the truck capacity of 15 cubic yards and the bucket capacity of 3.3 cubic yards, 4.55 buckets are required to fully load the dump truck.

In practice, however, it is only practical to have an integer number of loads.

Thus, the operator of excavator is able to use either four or five swings the load a dump truck.

So let’s analyze each of these scenarios.

Four Bucket Option

In the four bucket option, the excavator loads a truck with four buckets of 3.3 cubic yards.

The load of dump truck will be 13.2 cubic yards, which is less than its 15 cubic yards capacity and is acceptable.

By multiplying the volume, which is 13.2 cubic yards, by the density of the soil, the weight of the load will be 28’644 pounds which is less than the maximum weight limit and is acceptable.

According to the handbook, each bucket takes 20 seconds (details will be discussed in module 4), so the total loading time is calculated as:

Thus, the loading time of a truck with four buckets will be 80 seconds.

Five Bucket Option

In the five bucket option, however, the excavator cannot load a truck with five full buckets of 3.3 cubic yards, because it exceeds the 15 cubic yards capacity of the dump truck. In practice, the last bucket will be half full and it loads trucks to its full capacity of 15 cubic yards.

By multiplying the volume, which is 15 cubic yards, by the density of the soil, the weight of the full load will be 32’550 pounds which is less than the maximum weight limit and is acceptable

Since each bucket takes 20 seconds, the total loading time is 100 seconds.

Step 2: Haul time

We have to use dump truck’s performance chart to calculate its speed, then we can find the haul time.

As described, performance chart requires: 1) truck total weight, 2) total resistance of the road

The weight of the truck in four and five buckets scenarios are:

The empty weight of truck is 36’860 pounds, and by adding the load weight in both scenarios, total weights are calculated.

Finding Total Resistance

The next step is to find the total resistance of the road.

Haul road form loading site to dump area is a 3.2 mile gravel road with uphill grade of 1%.

As discussed in previous module, rolling resistance of a road depends of the surface material type and condition.

Since dump trucks have rubber tires and it is a gravel road, the rolling resistance is 20 to 35 kg per metric tons.

Finding Rolling Resistance

Thus, the rolling resistance of the surface is 20-35 kg/m ton or 40-70 lb/ton.

Let’s use a number is this range, for instance 60 lb/ton, which is equivalent to 3% (20 lb/ton is 1%)

Therefore, the total grade resistance in haul direction is:

Finding Haul Speeds

Then we can find the haul speeds using the performance chart of this truck.

We need to interest the weights in four and five buckets, which are 65504 and 69410 pounds, with the total resistant of 4%.

Then the haul speed in four and five bucket scenarios are 20 and 18 miles per hour, respectively.

The speed of the dump truck in five bucket scenario is slower than the four bucket, because the dump truck is about 4000 pounds heavier.

Step 2. Haul Times

Given the speeds and the hauling distance of 3.2 miles, the haul times will be:

The haul time for the heavier trucks with five buckets is about one minute longer than the haul time for the trucks loaded with four buckets.

Step 3: Return time

Return times using the performance chart

Since the slope in return direction is downhill , thus the total resistance is 3% (for rolling resistance) – 1% (for downhill slope) = 2%

The weight of the trucks in return trips is the same and equals to the empty weight of truck, which is about 37000 pounds.

This weight does not intersect the 2% total resistance, which means that the truck can return with the maximum speed, which is 35 miles per hour.

Finding Haul Times

The haul time in both cases is 5 and a half minutes.

Step 4: Dump time

The time for queuing and maneuvering is expected to be 2 minutes in this case.

But it should be mentioned that it has to be estimated in every jobsite.

Step 5: Cycle times

This table provides the detailed cycle times for four and buckets scenarios.

The truck cycle time in each scenario equals to total times of these four processes.

In these two scenarios, trucks loaded with five buckets finish a complete cycle in 19.83 minutes, whereas dump trucks with four buckets of load finish a cycle in 18.43 minutes.

Dump trucks with four buckets of load require less time to load, and because they are lighter than fully loaded trucks, they can travel the haul distance in a shorter time.

Step 6: Number of truck required

This step describes the process to calculate the optimum number of trucks required for a loading unit.

The optimum number of trucks is the configuration in which all the dump trucks are active in the cycle. For example, they are either being loaded, hauling, dumping, or returning.

In addition, there should always be a truck ready for the loader.

For example, it takes two minutes for an excavator to load a dump truck and the total cycle time of a dump truck is 10 minutes.

So if we assign only one dump truck, the excavator should wait for eight minutes to load the dump truck again. But if we add four more dump trucks to the system, we can optimize the system where all equipment are working at the same time, in which the dump trucks are active and the excavator always has a customer for loading.

Optimum Number of Trucks

This table shows the optimum number of required trucks for a loader using four and five bucket scenarios. The optimum number of trucks is equal to truck cycle time divided by the loader cycle time.

In practice, however, the number of assigned trucks should be integer. So if the calculation results is 11.9, we assign 12 trucks to the process.

Step 7: Production of fleet

Finally we can calculate the production of the entire fleet, including all the assigned trucks and excavator, in one hour.

The following formula can be used for the production.

This formula basically calculates the volume of the moved material in one hour, which directly depends on the number of trucks in the system (show the left red rectangle), the volume of material transported by a truck in a cycle (show the middle red rectangle), and the number of cycles completed by each dump truck in an hour (show the right red rectangle),

This table provides the results for the two scenarios using four and five bucket approaches with different number of trucks.

In this case, loading trucks with four buckets provides better production than five buckets, but more trucks are needed.

This analysis , however, only considers the overall production, and adding more trucks costs more, and the cost of assigning more trucks should be analyzed together with the production gains to achieve the best result.

Quiz 1:

Find the speed of a dump truck with 70000 lb gross weight in an uphill road with 3% slope and 80 lb/ton rolling resistance.

a. 7 mph

b. 9 mph

c. 12 mph

d. Impossible

Quiz 2:

Find the speed of a dump truck with 90000 lb gross weight in an uphill road with 1% slope and 60 lb/ton rolling resistance.

a. 3 mph

b. 7 mph

c. 12 mph

d. Impossible

Summary of Unit 2

1. Cyclic earthmoving operations can be analyzed by dividing them into smaller processes.

2. Duration of each process can be calculated using the manufacturer handbook and jobsite conditions.

3. Different scenarios should be analyzed to determine the best production.

Equipment Cost

Overall equipment expenses include two types of cost:

• Ownership cost

• Operating costs

Ownership Cost

Ownership cost include fixed costs:

• Initial capital cost

• Depreciation

• Interest cost

• Insurance

• Taxes

• Storage and miscellaneous

Initial Capital Cost

This is the cost of equipment acquisition which on average makes up to 25% of the overall cost of equipment during its useful life. Initial capital cost includes:

• Manufacturers price extra options+ sales tax, some customers might want to install include optional features in their equipment, such as machine control systems or safety cameras, which increase the initial cost

• Cost of shipment. This could be a significant cost, especially for oversize haulage of large equipment

• Cost of assembly and erection. Some of the larger equipment are transported in pieces and has to be assembled on jobsite. This requires using large cranes and skilled personnel which adds to the initial cost

Depreciation

Depreciation is the decline in the market value of a heavy equipment due to age, deterioration, wear, and also obsolescence.

To calculate depreciation, we need:

• Initial capital cost, which we already discussed)

• Useful life: the number of years expected to used the equipment

• Salvage value: the expected cash value (if it is sold) of the equipment at the end of useful life.

Salvage Value

Salvage value is difficult to estimate and depends on the type of equipment.

Machines with diverse and layered functionalities can be sold in high prices in later years, because they can be used for other purposes.

For example, medium-size bulldozers are usually used for heavy excavation and ripping operations in the early years, and then can be assigned for light operation such as a stripping and spreading in later years.

But the salvage value is much less than the initial value for the single use equipment.

This graph shows the salvage value for two different equipment types, and as it is presented, a well-maintained multipurpose equipment will have a much higher salvage value than a limited purpose equipment at the end of their useful life.

Estimating Depreciation

Two common method to estimate deprecation of equipment are:

• Straight-line depreciation

• Sum-of-years’-digit depreciation

1. Straight-line depreciation

Where Dn is the depreciation in the year n

IC is the initial capital cost in dollars

SV is the salvage value in dollars

TC is the tire and track costs in dollars

N is the useful life of the equipment in years

This method assumes that the equipment depreciation is linear and equal in every year of the useful life of the equipment

2. Sum-of-years’-digit depreciation

Where Dn is the depreciation in the year n

Year n digit in reverse order, for example if the useful life for an equipment is 7 years, we use 7 to calculate for the year 1 and 6 for year 2 and so on

IC is the initial capital cost in dollars

SV is the salvage value in dollars

TC is the tire and track costs in dollars

N is the useful life of the equipment in years

Unlike straight line methods, this method does not assumes a linear depreciation for the equipment, and it considers faster depreciation in early years of the useful life of the equipment

Straight-line vs sum-of-years’-digit depreciation

This graph show the difference of the two models

This line shows the equal depreciation in the straight-line method

This curve shows the unequal depreciation in the sum-of-years method, in which the depreciation is accelerated in years and slows down in the later years

Depreciation Example

Use the two methods to calculate depreciation of the following grader.

Initial cost (including all other costs): $125,000

Tire cost: $15,000

Useful life: 8 years

Salvage value: $17,000

Depreciation Solution

1. Using Straight-line depreciation

2. Using Sum-of-years’-digit depreciation

Depreciation Chart

In this table, the first second row show the depreciation in each year using the straight line method and as you can see, the depreciation amount is constant in all years.

Sum-of-years’-digit depreciation values In the third row, however, differ dramatically, as the depreciation is much larger in early years and decreases by time, which is more realistic

Quiz 1:

Use the sum-of-years’-digit method to calculate depreciation of the following loader in the year 3.

Initial cost (including all other costs): $190,000

Tire cost: $20,000

Useful life: 7 years

Salvage value: $30,000

a. $11,000

b. $15,000

c. $20,000

d. $25,000

Interest Cost

Interest cost is the annual cost of the capital invested into the machine which is converted into an hourly cost. The interest cost is based on the average value of equipment during its useful life:

So the company has to apply the expected rate of return on the average value of equipment during its useful life.

Where P is the average value of the equipment

Year n digit in reverse order, for example if the useful life for an equipment is 7 years, we use 7 to calculate for the year 1 and 6 for year 2 and so on

IC is the initial capital cost in dollars

SV is the salvage value in dollars

TC is the tire and track costs in dollars

N is the useful life of the equipment in years

Unlike straight line methods, this method does not assumes a linear depreciation for the equipment, and it considers faster depreciation in early years of the useful life of the equipment

Insurance, taxes, and storage costs

These cost depends on different factors, such as the market and location, and usually expressed in the form of a percentage rate. Common percentages are provided in this table*:

Interest Cost = 3-9 %

Insurance = 2-5%

Tax = 1-3%

Storage = 0-1.5%

Ownership Cost: Example

Calculate the hourly rate of ownership cost for the third year of operation of a roller with following information:

Operation: 280 days/year; 7 h/working day

Initial cost: $85,000

Tire cost: $10,000

Useful life: 6 years

Salvage value: $12,000

Interest rate of investment: 7%

Insurance: 2.5%

Taxes: 2%

Storage: 0.5%

Solution:

Depreciation cost in third year:

D3 = $120,000

$6.12/h

Average annual investment:

Total ownership cost in third year 6.12+3.34 = $9.46

Quiz 2:

Ownership cost of a machine does NOT include:

a. Interest

b. Taxes

c. Maintenance

d. Depreciation

Operating Cost

Operating cost includes:

• Fuel: depends on the equipment power and the working conditions

• Lubrication and hydraulic oil

• Tires

• Maintenance and repair costs

Ownership and Operating Cost

This graph presents the behaviors of the ownership and operating costs of an equipment over time.

This curve shows the ownership cost per hour of operation, and it decrease overtime. The main reason is the deprecation, because the value of the machine decrease over time, thus the ownership cost drops as well.

In contrast, the hourly operating cost increase by the age of equipment, because equipment breakdown more frequent and the repairs for the equipment can be very costly. In addition, older equipment typically consume more fuel than the new equipment with similar power.

Equipment Profitability

Here, we are going to borrow the previous graph to describe the profitability of the equipment

As it is presented, the profit of an operating equipment increase by time, because the ownership cost drops and the operating cost is rather low.

But after a certain time, the profit starts to drop due to accelerated increase in the operating cost of the machine.

Based on these concept, economic life of a machine is the time period that the profits increase and reaches the maximum level.

Profit life of a machine is the time period that the machine operation provides profit, or in other words, the output is larger than the ownership and operating cost.

Physical life of a piece of equipment is the time the reliable operation of the machine is no longer possible, because it frequently breaks down and maintenance and repairs cost dramatically increase overtime. At this point, the machine should be scrapped.

Replacement Decisions

At the end of the economic life a machine, decision makers need to decide on the replacement option to maintain profitability of the operations. The options are:

• Buy or direct ownership

• Rent or short term alternative to use a piece of equipment

• Lease which is long-term agreement to use a piece of equipment

For replacement decision, we need to:

• Estimate the ownership cost of the alternatives

• Estimate the operating cost of the alternatives

• Estimate the profit

• Estimate payback period

• Pick the item with lower payback time

Quiz 3:

When is the suitable time to replace a machine:

a. end of physical life

b. end of economic life

c. end of profit life

Summary of Unit 3:

• Overall equipment expenses include ownership and operating costs

• Ownership cost include fixed costs: namely, depreciation, interest cost, insurance, taxes and storage costs

• Operating cost includes fuel, lubrication and hydraulic oil, tires, and maintenance and repair costs

• Mangers need to estimate economic life of a piece of equipment and evaluate replacement alternatives

Summary of Module 3:

• We discussed how to estimate required power, available power, and usable power of equipment

• A framework to estimate equipment cycle time and productivity using fixed time, loading time, and variable time was demonstrated

• We discussed ownership and operating costs of the equipment and described economic life and replacement alternatives of the equipment

2. Which of the following graphs does correctly represent the value of a piece of equipment over time ?

a. 5,150kg

b. 6,650 kg

c. 6,350 kg

d. 6,050 kg

3. Given the table (use avg. values), find the total resistance for a scraper (low pressure tire) in a gravel road with 2% uphill slope.

a. 3%

b. 4%

c. 5%

d. 6%

4. Operating cost of a machine does NOT include:

a. Oil

b. Interest

c. Maintenance

d. Tires

5. Use the Straight line and sum-of-years’-digit methods to calculate depreciation of the following dump truck in the year 2.

Initial cost (including all other costs): $180,000

Tire cost: $25,000

Useful life: 6 years

Salvage value: $35,000
